review_title: Best and worst experience in T&O
pros: Meet friendly and capable people - be they local or foreigners.
cons:
1. Long working hours and many are doing 2-3 people's job.
2. Stable systems are overlooked and deemed "simple " or "easy" while systems that have problems every week are praised and people supporting it promoted every year.
3. There are entire floors of foreigners. So much so that they started a satellite office overseas in 2016 but yet these floors still exist and continue to grow. Majority are doing jobs that locals can do. Many are hired through personal relationships and not by merit. 
4. HR is only interested at managing headcount and cost by evading the 17% (Employer CPF contribution) by hiring foreigners hidden in the many outsourcing companies they use.
5. Unqualified staff increase troubleshooting issues by days and even weeks. Senior staff can screw up simple cert installations, server hardening and configurations. The best part is these people still manage to get promoted and bring in even more unqualified people.

review_title: Radical change in 3 years. Enjoyed the journey
pros:
Lots of people agenda. Each department runs their own people agenda eg. CNY decor competition, Friendship day presents by the bank, Monthly fruits day, Good level of IT/ departmental roadshows (posters, banners, free ice cream, popcorn, caricature, quiz). When everyone's spirit is raised, collaboration efforts are easier, people's ideas are respected. You see the older/long working staff adopting and trying out new ideas like kahoot, mentimenti, QR codes. The spirit of adapting is reflected in work, where change in processes are led by older staff to try to upskill. 

In the past 3 years, there was immense injection of life into the workforce. The topdown culture was really impacted when you see senior management leading by example (though of course sometimes they still revert back to old styles in urgent situations eg. printing decks, face to face meetings). 

Many advertisements and communications internally to keep the workforce up to date on analytics or customer journey. Some reception to younger generation suggestions. Generally nice people who you expect to become friends even after you leave.

Great CEO - achieve the nearly impossible task of culture transformation of a local bank with tons of staff with 20 years and above tenure. Not afraid to address the tough questions openly in town hall. Committed actions. (can't really say so for the 1-down levels)
cons: Internal conflict still remains. I guess it is the same everywhere, but as the senior mgt are there for long years, the conflict goes on , which may lead to childish opposing of ideas. Pay rise is low, but this is the trade off for stability. Bonus is consistent despite tough years. Internal mobility is tough as new jobs are in the new areas eg. data analytics, customer journey projects, digital banking. Hiring is done for these roles rather than internal mobility (due to obvious reason in the need to speed up transformation). Yet to see capable successors to the CEO.

pros: Great people and challenging environment. Great respect for the CEO and his vision who brought DBS to be the best bank in the world.
cons:
Depending in which organization you sit, you might encounter toxic behaviour from management. I'm specifically referring to the Digital Consumer Banking Technology, Big Data / AI group, which I'm part of.

Its leader drives the group like a dictator, often imposing questionable choices, micromanaging every piece of work and showing zero respect for people who put their time and effort in designing the best possible solutions. She will completely overturn decisions taken by her team, and when things do not go as planned (often because of decisions that she took) she will start blaming people publicly, yelling and screaming at everyone in meetings. People are so afraid of her and worried for their job that they do not have the courage to go against her anymore. This has created a toxic environment where everyone is encouraged to "suck up" to her and blame someone else when things do not go as planned. 

During the course of the years I have seen her hiring very strong individuals, throwing them in the "garbage" and forcing them to leave after few months or years just because they started disagreeing with her decisions. The unfortunate thing is that the bank keeps loosing smart people just because of her toxic behaviour and her total lack of respect for any human being.

Work recognition is solely at her discretion and only people who has learnt to "suck up" to her can progress in their career.

job_title: DBS Customer Service Officer (Contact Centre) in Singapore
pros:
-good benefits (salary & leave)
- trainers and mentors are helpful
cons:
- let me be very frank, before I decide to work at dbs, I read the reviews here and I thought maybe the job is still ok, but yes all the reviews shared are accurate
- pls know for this job as a CSO with dbs, you will need to manage calls all the time, basically just pick up calls non-stop, some may think this is easy, it is not bcos the calls will come in non-stop or quite frequent
- there are targets that we need to adhere, if during the call there are follow up, we need to do after our shift ends
- it is a monotonous job, if you dont mind answering calls and entertaining customers, then this job is perfect for you. If you second guess whether you can stand the calls and sitting for like 4hr then 1hr lunch then another 4hr straight, then better don't even try (I learn my lesson and its really not an interesting/fun job at all)
- on career progression, checked w managers, only after 1 year then can progress or go inter dept but performance must be really good. if want to progress to another departmemt, then must perform well in 2 years and all are subject to approval
- oh and for toilet breaks/other breaks, must minimize, all are counted in time spent, basically when you start shift, they will clock your time for all activities

review_title: Top down approach, good for retirement
pros:
Safe job, good for retirement if you’re looking to stay. Fixed progression and not much worry of how you’ll promote till you reach middle management. Being in the corporate segment, promotion is easier than the consumer segment. 

People are generally nice, politics happens but if you put departments aside, general attitude is that everyone is just there as a job, not to cut each other’s throats. 

DBS definitely does have some structure and processes in place being a large Corp, but has some ways to go to improve staff mindset to grow out of a domestic company culture.
cons:
Upper Management in SME segment are top down, not responsive to feedback, treats the company like an SME. A lot of things are done specifically for PR purposes, instead of long term vision of what is good for the customer and company. 

Recent years have seen multiple reorgs of the IBG34 segment. 

The working style from the top of segment is non strategic and instant gratifying. Without C suite expectation of digitalization and that being put in the score card, some things would not have happened. Multiple projects were undertaken instead of focusing on 2-3 key pillars to tackle and undertake.  

Instead of pouring dollars everywhere like over an ice cream sundae, instead think of how to create the most effective means of focusing the dollars for major effect. An example would be to improve internal platforms and adopt external tools like most digital banks.

pros:
1. Extremely close knit working relations, even between interns and the actual stuff
2. No cut-throat, pressure cooker environment; fairly lax and patient.
3. Chock full of resource and learning opportunities, only if you take the initiative to do so
4. Suitable competitive pay for university interns.
5. Supervisors willing to teach, only if you ask.
cons:
1. Most work done was menial- type this, fax that, print this, record that, fetch this, send that.
2. Presence of horrific maltreatment of interns, even stuff of urban myths. My fellow intern was made to routinely fetch coffee and food for the team, at one time even to clean and repair the air-con. 
3. Big gaps in between where the intern was simply left to do nothing.
4. Learning MUST be pro-active, if you don't take maximum effort to do so, the internship is a waste of time.
5. Subtle currents of politicking present.
6. Interns at DBS hold less prestige. This maybe due to the bank accepting polytechnic students as interns, which could perhaps lower the brand superiority of DBS as compared to the IBs.
8. Bureaucratic and rigid. Employees follow the proverbial rule book down to a T, many lack the ability to think critically, if not, are dissuaded to do so.
9. Lack of forward planning. Certain strategies and products were marketed and promoted without the relevant QC. Led to the presence of many disgruntled customers.
10. Employees lack pride in their job, especially those wedged in between senior management and lower levels; lack of difference in middle management could have resulted in this.
