review_title: Too many manager spoil the broth...
pros: DBS has good job security for personel, the pay is OK. People on the outside think it is a good place to work, so there is a bit of ego that goes with working there. It is also well repected name to have on the resume especially in Asia. Senior managemnt is usually top calibre. I assume as a GLC they do have to hire well at the top. It is an OK place for new grad, but you must get out after 18-24 months.
cons: DBS is a big dinosaur, as in slow to respond to new ideas and inflexible.  The middle management is overall farily poor. Middle management at DBS then to hoard information.  Cronisim and boys club mentatliy in middle management is raife. If you can get away with it you can hide in the management structure and do no work and make no decisions and get paid a semi decent salary. As such, there is alot of dead/old wood here.

review_title: Will always be a local bank
pros:
Cheap food 
Good onsite cafes
Lots of employee events based around food
Good staff benefits with shops etc
cons:
For a bank wanting to be viewed as a "startup" and compete with internationals, the use of local and regional languages very prevalent here and gives the impression of being unprofessional and staff as archaic. They don't monitor this as its deemed "social harmony" however as an Asian unable to understand any of the languages it feels borderline discriminatory.
Very dictatorship some times and some of the team members I worked with were very lazy and willing to make you look bad at first chance to cover themselves.  People complained alot yet still expected to be rewarded. Bad behaviour was rewarded as they didn't want the hassle of the Union to deal with.
Work life balance, if you do your hours and do a good job, you still get it thrown in your face if you leave on time or slightly early (no matter how many weekends or lunches you have worked through)
If you are sick this also gets used against you at your review time.

review_title: Senior Tech mgmt only track financials no clue about real tech
pros:
1. Decent perks, and engagement activities
2. Great brand recall in the market
3. is a good stepping stone for a better career
cons:
1. Low annual bonus and increment.
2. Severe politics
3. No constructive criticism, you're either aligned or a candidate to be thrown out, no acceptance of different opinions
4. Everyone wants to do stuff just because the CEO says so, not because it is the right thing to do
5. Want to follow GANDALF (Google, Amazon, etc) but don't know anything about technology, try for a few months then go buy vendor software instead of building something of their own
5. Business users are scared of admitting they don't know things and have to upskill, instead tech is at fault for every product failre
6. Product owners don't even know what their product is supposed to be doing, expect traditional Project managers to be Scrum masters and product owners both and just give them status update.

pros:
1) Good progressive culture
2) Good mix of young and old employees - the bank is pushing the older ones to keep up and the younger ones to give a helping hand. There is no shame in admitting outdated knowledge and skills in the current wave of digital disruption and transformation
3) Good salary pegged to above average market rates
4) Internal mobility is advocated
5) Good supply of new employees who bring new knowledge, skills and ideas
cons:
1) As in any other big organisations, politics is unavoidable and senior managers ring-fence their turf. Sometimes collaboration is lip-service.
2) There is still a fair amount of biases e.g. blue-eye staff
3) Too much rah rahs at time. We are good but can we be more humble?

review_title: Horrible company. Does not value top talent pool.
pros: Nothing to talk about. Absolutely disappointing.
cons:
Elitist mindset - Management Associates / Graduate Executives get all the perks and benefits, even though many of them don't make the cut. Consistent top performers (without career acceleration tracks) are constantly undermined and underpaid even though they may be much better than the MAs/GEs.

MAs / GEs can be paid as much as an AVP with the bank for 17 years. Even escalation to management and raising concerns to Human Resources on such glaring inequality results in a token few hundred dollars pay adjustment.

Not asking the bank to pay everyone equally, but to at least ensure competitive pay for TOP performers. However this seems to be too much for them as they value their MAs/GEs like precious gold.

After working in this bank for a number of years, my pay has stagnated even though I am consistently recognised as my department's top performer. Record profits, but no record increments or bonuses. I am now leaving for greener pastures with a taste of disgust in my mouth.

pros: A very diverse regional workforce, probably most diverse among some of the big local companies; very strong leadership and momentum to drive shareholder values; great transformation efforts; many employees journey efforts; great talent within the organisation; growth momentum.
cons:
There are still some legacy mentality,  process, thinking and even people politics which are hindering the pace of change and speed to react to the market changes. 
Middle management is inconsistent and some staff are not as driven (or could be complacent).

review_title: Singaporean bank culture. External image is changing, but still decades away from foreign banks in culture/capability.
pros: Pay seems to be at market. Lots of resources compared to other banks (in terms of headcount per team vs foreign banks). Strong retail bank and technology is improving. Stable job security. Relevancy as a corporate bank in Singapore. Transaction banking capability is improving fast. Leadership in transaction banking moving in the right direction.
cons: Still has a strong Singaporean culture compared to foreign banks. Learning and development from seniors is lacking. Banking knowledge development is lacking, ie. Not developing the skillset for future roles. Middle management VP to MD level likes to keep status quo. Deals not as exciting as foreign banks, and very short term thinking. Leaders do not have the varied experiences of working for other organisations (DBS whole career). Hours unusually long (face time). Lots of disgruntled employees.

review_title: Great life experience. A stepping stone to be in tbe customer service /banking industry.
pros: The best reasons are colleagues that care to lend a helping hand when newbies does not know how to go about a new transaction. That. Just that.
cons: Too many to mention. No work life balance at all. Some of the seniors are too rigid to their old-lifestyle that they never give the newbies a chance to speak up on new innovations. And,  having no work life balance makes the body system breakdown. You can't afford to take MC at all. MC is not an entitlement here.

review_title: Good staff benefits but poor work-life balance
pros:
- Decent compensation: above average in terms of starting salary for fresh university graduates 
- Good staff benefits: 24 days of annual leave + 2 days of family leave (effectively it's annual leave that you can't carry forward)
cons:
- Poor work life balance: frequent OT. Almost impossible to complete one's work without doing OT on a regular basis. In fact, OT is like a "default" activity.
- Management is overly ambitious, introducing more changes and taking on more projects than the staff can handle (and that's why staff have to OT so often)
- Management doesn't want to acknowledge the shortage of manpower.

pros: Decent staff benefits e.g. share scheme, staff rates for loans etc, company great in marketing itself (best digital bank etc), better off to be a shareholder instead
cons: Annual salary increment is worst than inflation, mgt’s excuses for low bonus and pay increment will be budget not met but you still see the bank achieving record profits and senior mgt getting huge pay raises, layers of bureaucracy to get things done

pros:
Depends on which dept you work with. Great boss at IBG, worst Boss at contact centre. Extreme differences. 
Tons of perks
Supportive and understanding boss at IBG who care about you and your family.
cons:
Contact centre -  management has no empathy especially when you took leave for urgent family matter. They will stressed you by calling you Everyday to ask when you are coming back to work. Need to ballot for popular days to take leave eg cny, Christmas. 
There has a special HR for contact centre only who will only side the management. 
Thankfully I managed to transfer to IBG which is more human. The work life significant changed Fr hell to heaven.

pros: The ARM in DBSPB does everything for the RM and ICs, so you literally get insight into every single function from account opening and KYC to investment portfolio construction, order taking, dealing and tracking, credit approval, credit monitoring and review, everything you can think of and cannot think of. And there's also retail banking stuff (credit cards, cash withdrawal, CNY new notes omg)
cons: On the flip side, you literally get paid half of the foreign banks for triple the amount of work load... and if you don't get a good boss, then good luck because the RM will always always always push the responsibilities and blame to the ARM.

pros:
Excellent benefits.

This sales role is great for smooth talkers as you will earn well if you can sell often.
cons:
A Wealth Planning Manager is just a fancy name for a salesman, and you will sell mostly insurance. 

Your entire work-life revolves around the sales numbers you generate for your manager for that month and whether you exceed your previous month's target.

No sales or unsatisfactory sales numbers means no work-life balance as you'll be expected to stay until potentially 8-10pm most of the week to cold call.

Join if you can handle rejection on a daily basis.

Turnover is very high due to the factors mentioned above. As such you will have to deal  dissatisfied clients from previous Wealth Planning Managers often.

pros:
- Family-like culture.
- Friendly environment.
- Financially stable and strong.
- Employee shares scheme.
cons:
- Needs to allocation more budget for system enhancement. Staff are doing many work-a-around manually due to system limitations. We were told our department budget for system enhancement in 2013 is $0.00. So demoralized and lost motivation to enhance anymore manual processes..
- Many staff (including both lower ranking staff and senior managers) are seasoned employees, hence might be too comfortable to challenge status quo processes.
- Too many layers of bosses to clear when it comes to reporting figures or decision making, when bosses have different direction, decisions made at lower level will be overwritten without being considered much.

pros: DBS may not be a big player on the regional or the global playing field, but this is not necessarily a bad thing. My sense is that the ambition of the Senior management team to reinvent banking provides employees who are willing to be pioneers, an opportunity to create a new model in Asian banking. In this size, the relatively small size and relatively flat structure are advantages. The bank has also recently revisited its core values and the new set of values seem sensible and resonate with staff. The environment is generally collegial.
cons: The biggest challenge is dealing with legacy thinking (that DBS is the biggest bank in Singapore and can therefore rest on its laurels). This is particularly the case when trying to expand regionally. Taking what is working in Singapore, and assuming it will work in the region can sometimes be misleading.

pros: Good employee benefits, stable employment.
cons:
HIGHLY political organisation, thus it speaks for its value. Overall direction changes every year. 
This is a big cruise trying to finally steer away from the quay towards the sea.
There's a lack of real workforce to engineer the change.
Long hours & hard work are usually a result of "what boss thinks is right", without much real contribution towards the collective progress for the bank.
Poor communication from higher management. 
Unbalanced incentive structure, does not encourage efficiency & talent.

review_title: Progressive bank with a great CEO at the helm
pros:
- Great CEO, together with a strong and experienced senior management team
- Progressive and forward-looking, which is largely a result of the good work by the senior management in steering the ship forward in the past half decade 
- 24 days of annual leave + 2 days of family leave in a year. Other staff benefits are pretty comprehensive too
- Amicable and supportive culture. Colleagues are friendly and helpful in general
- The bank seems well-positioned to handle and overcome the challenges in the industry
cons:
- Still pretty hierarchical, and the bank doesn't seem to have enough courage to truly fast-track or give more rapid promotions to high-performing employees. Promotions still follow a roughly fixed timeline, unless you consistently turn in performances of the standards of Piyush Gupta or Jamie Dimon
- Other than that, everything seems good

pros: Tons of new technologies to learn, company advocates catching up to the modern stack. Meetup events aplenty.
cons: The nicest way i can say this con is politics. The not-very-nice way to say it is fickle minded director. As a developer in the field, you are bounded by the direction of the director and the guides set out by the architects. Problem is there are so many architects fighting amongst each other that your technology requirements change literally everyday. Not to mention that they do not value developers, but the 'minds' who delivered the first idea.

review_title: A place for those who like to make a difference!
pros: The bank is changing for the better, new breakthrough, more creative ways to perform work, suitable for those who wanted to contribute and make a difference, The bank is growing, there is a lot of opportunity and many new job created.  CEO and his one down are committed to practice what they preach. Great place to work for woman and working mother.
cons: Since the bank changing quite rapidly, with more diversity, understanding the way people working and their culture is crucial for survival tips in this company.

pros:
- Great CEO with great visions and decisions. 
- Good bosses and colleagues.
- Flat structure, subordinates can challenge managerial decisions.
- Motivated spirits and can-do culture with innovation push.
- AI and data driven.
cons:
- Mediocre benefits but HR is still very excited to tell you about. Nothing good really to retain staff if they have other options.
- AI and data obsessed, sometimes leading to counter-productive initiatives
- Some big bosses sounds like maniacs keep sending poems and quotes around. They should have worked for Tesla.
- Old folks are like work-for-life wrecks. New folks from other banks must have brought life and positive changes to DBS.
- Iron rice bowl is the old story.

review_title: No. of days leave is the most attractive
pros: 24- that's quite a high number of days of leave you're entitled to. Awesome, but many don't get to clear the leave cus there's always so much work, and so many freeloaders in the team.
cons: Bosses like to hire "the best" talents - either people who have obviously oversold their credentials, or people who're really good in what they do but aren't utilised well.

review_title: Good future for the bank on the outside but internal problems
pros: Employment benefits. Enthusiastic culture about things they are trying to drive. Effort to open communication channels with staff straight to top management.
cons: People - many seniors have the dated mindset. Enforcing hierarchy in management style. Difficult to bring change. Split locations make travelling tedious. Normal working hours are beyond normal if you are a responsible employee who won't just drop your work when the minimum knockoff time is reached if work is not complete.

review_title: Bank that is growing very rapidly and its growth speed brings on numerous new opportunities for the employees
pros:
- Stable and overly competitive or political
- Improving HR benefits
- Co-workers are genuinely supportive and considerate
- Very rewarding if you have a supportive boss or if you are in the MAP
cons:
- limited overseas exposure or overseas posting
- no flexible work hours or arrangements (the culture is not deep set yet).
- can be political as many colleagues have been in DBS for more than 10 years
- Slow to react and difficult to implement new ideas
- too many layers of senior management who are not hands on

pros: Pay well, stable job,  company making profit. If you can survive and know how to handle your boss, a good place for retirement.
cons: No enough resource and time to do right work. Instead of doing your professional job,  struggling on pressure from boss and boss boss. Not professional in most cases. more time spend on ppt than real work. Have to hide issue instead work on it. Compare with other banks, over secured IT reduce efficiency and confuses all newbies.  The security team obviously don't know how to play with MAS.

pros: Work-life balance, optional family medical benefits, annual leave 24 days and with additional childcare leave. Flexi-cash benefit for lifestyle/dental/insurance. IT technology are improvised and up-to-date. Many systems are available to use at work which are very good compared to some banks which don't pull in resource to upgrade systems, intranet information are well-equipped. Other department staff are generally helpful. Can find a handful of colleagues working in the bank for many years. Bonus is better than EU banks and competitive with local banks.
cons: Too many Management hierarchies, management politics, too many systems sometimes to find what you want. Each team/business unit have their own work-culture. Really dependable on your direct supervisor and management to make it a joyful working environment.

pros:
Singaporean bank - many singaporeans around. Pro-Asian
Work life balance present at times.
cons:
Use of singlish/Hokkien/cantonese/chinese is common here. Feels unprofessional at times. Joined straight after graduation, and to hear colleagues (staff who have been with the bank for 15 years and more) speak languages other than english feels  unprofessional.

In addition, graduates from local uni not as competitively paid than if they were to work in foreign bank. DBS is losing graduates/talent from local U fast, after 2-3 years. Many peers have left, from across bank wide.

review_title: Lots of KPI to meet and non stop calls
pros: Pay is quite decent, leave given amount looks good at the surface, some welfare given, close working relationship with superior and colleagues
cons: Very challenging KPIs to meet, management only seem to be blinded by KPIs without knowing the issues on the ground, some processes too troublesome and only seem to make customer in a worse position than previously, leaving customer service officers to bear the brunt of their frustration. Slow to adapt to new technologies compared to competitors, impossible to take leave unless u apply a year in advance.

review_title: Disconnect between what they say and what is real
pros:
1. Ambitious and take up challenging projects to match industry leadership
2. Very good employee benefits
3.  attempt to work with new tech stack and build new solutions
cons:
1. Racist staff where Indians and Indonesians are treated with contempt
2. In normal conversations sometimes the foreigners and local reference crops up
3. Managers don't understand any new tech stack and will to understand is minimal too.
4. Hopeless senior management has double standards, highlight something in open forums but actual practices differ.
5. Original ideas don't matter to anyone, they try to copy Google, Netflix, and other tech giants blindly without thinking if the ideas fit the bank's own use cases.

pros: Top management are rather dedicated. However, the dedication is not filtered down to the senior management.
cons:
- Archiac culture where you are supposed to do as told and not offer your views. 
- My senior management enjoys their staff to brown-nose them. 
- Very rank-conscious and those AVPs and above tend to talk down to those at lower ranks.
- Performance evaluation not very fair as your bonus is dependent on which top notch favours you and willing to put in a good word for you. If your boss doesn't like you, you're doomed.

review_title: Great place to learn and progress
pros: Provides good training class for new employees. Although the learning curve is steep, senior colleagues are all very friendly and willing to teach and guide you along the way. Pay is very attractive compare to other local banks in Singapore. Work culture tend to vary from different branch manager or service manager, but overall they managers try to avoid work politics and lay a healthy work environment. Continuous learning opportunity!
cons: Long working hours. People with difficulty managing time or come out with a suitable daily routine would find themselves wearing out very quickly. Work with an end goal in mind!

review_title: ITT SG Leadership condones DAH2 senior leadership behaviour
pros: DBS is more than family to long timers. No one person can be made accountable for worsening the culture of ITT at DAH2. In the interest of well being of people, it is urged that people use 360 degree feedback, pigeon hole and my voice comments to get issues addressed. It is not sensible to malign reputation of DBS on glassdoor. If you think you are being unheard by HRBP and various forums, reach out to CEO for inputs and help.
cons: None that I have witnessed in last decade.

pros:
1. Bank believes strongly in talent rotation. Priority is given to internal staff to apply for transfer.
2. Good leaders and top management who are capable of steering the company to greater heights.
cons:
1. Poor work life balance and long working hours.
2. Does not pay as well compared to other banks.
3. People in top positions are usually foreign talent. Hires a lot of foreigners compared to Singapore Citizens.

review_title: Innovation without cleaning up legacy items
pros: Stable company, good benefits
cons: Too many legacies issues. Sometimes new staff is just throw into the sea to work with no guidances or guidance from people who doesn't know the whole picture - this results in operational risk - which ironically is what the bank is trying to minimize. Most dept will just paint the good pic. Bank encourage innovations but sometimes there's so many ideas from depts which are implemented that even employees are confused. Employees are already tired as it is and they have to cope with new learning. If you truly wan innovation - clean up the legacy items first.

pros: DBS has the best perks for any employees. Generous with their "freebies" such as random catering of the in trend snacks (YOLE, Ice cream etc), always stocking up the pantry with food, random food buffet,   always mindful of other religion's diet etc
cons: Aggressive push for outcomes/ good stats. Quantity over quality. Best CSO are awarded based on highest number of calls instead of best quality CSATs. Some CSOs has high call numbers because they constantly transfer calls that they were supposed to handle to other departments. While others have lower call numbers because they answer these transferred calls.

review_title: Backend - No work life balance & depressing working culture
pros: Good staff benefits, 26 days annual leave and stable company
cons:
Senior management uses condescending words and threaten to put negativitve comments in appraisal as their management style when they heard not good feedback and they do not listen to explanation 

Do not practice open communication, seniors will "complain" to managers when clarification and miscommunication can be avoided by just thrashing out in person. Bullying by seniors-complain to bosses instead of just face-to-face clarifications and usually managers will side seniors or "scared" of them to be objective. Shouts at new staff in public when seniors found a mistake made. 

No worklife balance

Very local culture, i.e. Boss and seniors (regardless of rank as long as they are there longer than you) are always right

review_title: Good learning ground for fresh grads
pros: Good training programme, especially beneficial for fresh grads. Good mentorship (depends on the branch you get in). DBS provides you most of the necessity for you to work (training, mentorship, sales materials, even an iPad). Good career progression.
cons: With all the necessity provided, the rest is on your own to survive the competitive sales arena. In sales, you don't earn more for working hard and longer hours. It is best fit for the sleepless wolf. A place of constant progression and contemplation, a place to push yourself and hone your ability to focus, to excel, and to achieve consistent sales targets for the company.

pros:
Good Facilities
Good Pay and Benefits.
cons:
Very long hours.
Toxic and political work culture.
Long meetings not talking about work.
Waste a lot of time doing presentation slides for internal meetings.

review_title: Technology Teams is a big mess among teams
pros: Colleagues are friendly and professional. Great place to work if you don't have to deal with technology teams.
cons: Teams within Technology cannot even work together. There is no overall architect to provide solution governance. Developers are not experience and solutions are half baked.

review_title: Senior Management are active and committed to the growth of the bank
pros:
- Good work life balance
- Easy access to Senior management 
- Meritocratic
- Stable job
- Smart/Hardworking individuals will stand out naturally in the organization
- 2 + 2 years internal mobility program gives staff an opportunity to explore other functions within the bank
- Plenty of opportunities in Asia region. Bank is aggressively expanding into Indonesia, TW, HK. China, India
- Robust Management Associate Programme
cons:
- Staff welfare & benefits can be improved
- Middle management may not be as committed
- Somewhat conservative work culture

review_title: You need to mix with the right people
pros: Big brand name on your CV. The org is so huge that you learn alot of peocesses and it made you a more resilient person at work.
cons: Political. You need to suck up to the right people to climb ul the rank. Communication is closed. If speak up too much and is comments which are not desirable, you will be marked.

pros:
A good starting ground for wealth management industry
Good benefits
cons:
During KPI months from Jan to Sep, expect to work every single day of the week. Saturday banking and Sunday roadshows included. Roadshows are not compulsory but there is peer pressure to attend. 
Commission structure is very bad. Top performers in the region may not even be able to get 5 figure payout per quarter. 
Very insurance focused. A lot of product pushing.

review_title: disappointing work culture for such an established company
pros: nothing positive yet to mention
cons:
no proper training for newbies - expect you to learn everything on the job nevermind, but dont even have a proper knowledge database to refer to

things get done at a snail pace - request for proper equipment, access can take more than a month

management frowns if you leave on the dot - even interns work up to more than 12 hours a day, work life balance my foot

pros:
Able to meet people from all walks of life.
Suitable for people who are customer-oriented and enjoy meeting and talking to people.
cons:
Branch manager micro manage - toilet break duration, mobile phone to be kept in locker, permission to go for toilet. No flexibility in work schedule, branch manager will remove your leave/off if lack of manpower. 
Have to hit non-service related kpi - insurances sales, number of loan referral.

pros: Nice open office that is just spacious enough but close enough for interaction with other colleagues. Good benefits.
cons: Performance appraisal is still somewhat dubious as staff will not know how they are rated against what KPIs. How they are ranked and graded is dependent on how well their supervisors argue and stand up for their work. Better hope your boss is the more outspoken type.

review_title: Up and Coming Bank to Work For
pros:
DBS is a bank on the rise. No doubt it has a lot of legacy issues to deal with but it is definitely on the right path to establishing itself as a significant player in the Asian market. The Bank's position in the Singaporean market in the areas of Treasury and Markets, Corporate Banking, and Capital Markets are unassailable. DBS is very strong in these areas and is performing very well. Furthermore, with the addition of Piyush as CEO who is an exceptional visionary and executor, DBS not only has a clear vision for the future but now has someone who can actually get it done. For people who are interested to work for DBS, the things you can look forward to are:
 - Strong universal banking capabilities in Asia thus allowing for a great number of opportunities an exposure assignments. 
- Excellent working culture in the sense that people can be very nurturing and respectful
- A lot of leave (though the caveat is that you won't necessarily be able to use it all)
- Great senior management who are not only competent but personable and empathetic
- Constant flow of incoming deals
cons: As I mentioned, legacy. The Bank has a laundry list of legacy issues to iron out which include dated IT systems, and redundant staff stemming from years of mismanagement. As such, things can take a while to get moving at times and paper work is never ending. Furthermore, compensation can leave a lot to be desired. Though it is the highest paying of all the local banks in Singapore, it still does not compare to some of the other foreign banks who not only have better pay but also superior benefits.

review_title: Good benefits but highly political organization
pros: Good staff benefits and working environment. Work life balance.
cons: Highly political company. Top leadership is clear with their direction but their one or  two downs are reluctant to give direction and take accountability. Often, leaving working level in various department as boats heading to different directions.

review_title: Great benefits to make up for the "suffering"
pros: 20++ days leave, free food, medical benefits, helpful colleagues
cons:
Salary is quite high but not high enough for the challenges we had to go through
Difficult customers; always be prepared to listen to angry comments and even mockery
High expectations from management and managers (E.g. Targets, KPIs)
Can take on toll on you emotionally and physically

pros:
- Safe local bank to work.
- good work life balance.
cons:
- compensation is not good compared to other MNCs.
- For new joiners its a struggle to learn as no documents are available or not shared by seniors.
- No training given to new joiners and is expected to learn everything themselves.
- Processes are not properly defined which makes things very difficult to achieve. Takes a very long time chasing/following up people to deliver the work.

pros:
The benefits are good.
The number of annual leave is great!
There is the company's club that gives special deals for leisure.
You get good rates if you want to get a loan.
cons:
Absolutely no work life balance.
Colleagues are not exactly friendly.
Lots of regulations to abide and be cautious of.

pros: Good amount of annual and medical leave
cons: Bad corporate culture, tall hierarchical structure where you’ll need to get approvals from 5 different departments to get one thing approved. Salary is lower in comparison to other banks and incentives keep getting cut thus leading to minimal recognition for your hard work. An award winning digital bank with backward systems and processes which makes day to day work highly inefficient (and they penalise you’re by cutting your incentives if you make any errors) overall would not recommend.

review_title: Generous bank but management not yet there
pros:
-Lots of benefits since it's a big company
-Lots of leaves
-Good medical benefits
-Nice Colleagues (Contact Centre Department to be specific)
cons:
-Understaffed
-A lot of KPI's that stresses employees
-A lot of changes employees have to keep up in a weekly/daily basis
-Some of the management don't know what they are doing, everything seems experimental
-Career progression is slow
-Lots of politics.

pros: Managers and Colleagues are nice. But gossip spreads like wildfire - So I don't know what to think of them now. Great benefits on paper. If you like shift work, like me - great. When you're welcomed into the company, they are upfront about how tough the job is.
cons: If you're not good with time management, cases will just pile up and you'll get new cases daily too. Depending on how you deal with stress and management, the workload will drown you. Phones ring non-stop. You're going to be told off by nasty customers almost everyday. Liaising with other business units for follow up replies is tedious. KPI updated hourly so it depends on how you take it. Every second plays into your KPI - how fast you answer the call, the actual call time, after call time, personal break (only 10 mins a day) and every second/minute that exceeds your break. Very steep learning curve, especially when you're on more splits than your seniors. If you're on chat - prepare for concurrent chats. Customers be it on chat or phone - are usually there to complain or demand for something ridiculous. When cases are escalated, managers tend to give in to them which made whatever you initially told customers REDUNDANT because you could have done it yourself but no - not according to terms and conditions. As they develop apps, campaigns and platforms frequently, there are always new issues. Turnover rate is high and with good reason - understaffed, high MC rates thus more workload for everyone else. Moving to another department is only if you've been there 2 years and are a top performer. So if your stats aren't great, it's a waste.

pros:
I have left the bank but will encourage people to join DBS should opportunity arises. 

People are generously nice there across business and support units. I happened to join the right team with good managers and supportive colleagues. While OT is expected in banking and especially in operation, my OT hours was acceptable (occasionally beyond 7pm).  

Overall benefits are good with the  most generous AL among the 3 local banks. 

Internal transfer are  widely advocated in the bank.
cons: I would have stayed on if there is better bonus and increment.

pros: Can't think of any.  I am looking for job opportunities
cons: Have been with DBS Bank for several years now.  The culture is not healthy, everybody is trying to claim credit right from the top.  CEO wants every department to win awards to show to the world that the bank is great!  CEO claims credit for all the things that worked well, but forgot about all those glitches of the ATMs and blamed on the previous leaders prior to him.  Very Citibank centric, he brings ex-citibankers and they form cliques!

job_title: Senior Vice President EBusiness in Singapore
pros:
Good Brand in Banking space
Good CV Value
cons:
No clear online strategy
Lots of politics
No clear direction - people keep arguing and giving constant excuses
eBusiness Leadership is old and incompetent - no idea about latest trends. Just keep aping the other banks... nothing original here. No BIG ACTION, only BIG TALK

pros: Good Benefits. Depending on who your branch manager is, different standards applies for different branches
cons:
Although your position is the relationship manger but not really the case. 
If you're looking at managing finance or learning different financial instruments to clients, try something else. For relationship manager position, it's almost equivalent as being an insurance agent but you have the database of the bank. They don't really care about other KPI other than just insurance targets.

review_title: Strong top but weak middle management
pros: Stable and good worklife balance. CEO very proactive in fixing inefficiencies in the org and pushing for new innovations. Love the "employee journey" initiatives that focus on how to make work easier for employees. MDs i worked with are very knowledgeable with indepth domain knowledge.
cons: Very bureaucratic middle mgt (below MD level) slows down everything. Has reputation of promoting based on length of tenure - have seen dozens of very laid back individuals promoted to svp.

pros: Benefits provided by the bank
cons: Must tread carefully as there is lots of backstabbing, both by peers who step on you to get ahead, as well as by bosses of peers who want to help their staff get ahead. Such peers may not be good at their work. As long as they are able to act well and butter up to the bosses, they are then “entitled” to step on others in order to move ahead.

review_title: Best Bank in the World for a reason
pros:
* Great people, Awesome Management
* Good office decorations
* I have got a great manager.
cons:
* Codebase is too old, although they are trying their best to move out. It's not easy.
* Business still don't understand Agile development, so we are practicing bs agile. But, tech management is pushing really hard for it.

pros: If you like the family culture and relax environment this is the place for you to retire. Not for the driven and passion one!
cons:
Messy HR. Lapses in HR processes. I wonder does the HR ever works or is there a HR department?

A bank that is stuck in the 90s era. Yes, you may claim that you have the best digital bank but is the people mindset that needs to change and keep up with time.  What is the use of digital bank when the inner system is a big mess ?

review_title: Many good colleagues, but also fair share of terrible ones
pros: Cross-department/business line collaboration isn't as painful as in some other banks. Five on Five policy for Fridays is good, plus staff cafeteria with a bay view.
cons: They do tolerate some really verbally abusive managers for quite a while. And some senior guys who disappear for hours on end and don't show up for meetings.

pros:
- Great mentorship from senior level members
- Friendly environment, especially for interns who need help learning 
- After/during work social bonding (i.e. getting drinks with co-workers, going for lunch/dinner)
cons:
- Hard to interact with other interns, there could be more social events to network with them
- There is no post-internship job offers that are given to my knowledge, which is discouraging

review_title: Eye opening experience. Processes are much more convulated than you can imagine.
pros: It has great culture and environment. The people here are very friendly and helpful. There is also good corporate identity.
cons: Compensation is pathetic and perhaps even humiliating. If not so for senior positions, it is so for junior positions. Fresh graduates get 30% less from DBS than from other banks.

review_title: A fast paced bank but don't ever miss hitting your quarterly budget.
pros: U learn a lot and colleagues and systems are dynamic
cons: Immediate boss bends backward and forward. Staff end up feeling disgruntled and many senior guys had left. The bank itself has also become too big and too bureaucratic. The environment has turned political and driven solely by numbers

pros: The bank has a very clear vision and strategic priorities to achieve its digital transformation and sustainability agenda. CEO and leadership team cascade this message and continuously engage employees to ensure alignment and a strong sense of purpose. Incredibly fast paced but a great place for someone who wants to learn, work on exciting projects and stay ahead of the curve.
cons: The company is changing rapidly and this may be uncomfortable for some. For those new to the organisation, there's a need to adapt to contribute effectively.

pros: Friendly people, willing to teach and share, bank is doing well with good future prospects (as of 2013)
cons: Frequently have to travel between offices, which can be annoying and time-consuming, doesn't seem to have much work-life balance

pros:
it's a learning path process, good benefits for staff. 
pay increment , and high bonus paid depends on performance.
cons: Office politics exist everyday, cross sell insurance product for service staff with target 6-8 per month. no life balance, as your off day will be canceled if it is lack of manpower, no overtime pay for rank BEB and above,

review_title: Not as prestigious as you might think
pros:
1) You're working in the 'world's best bank'.
2) You can call yourself a banker.
3) Staff benefits are terrific.
cons:
Wow.. Where do I start?

If you're joining as a "Wealth Planning Manager", and believe that you're getting a prestigious job (particularly after those IQ tests they put you through online), you're drinking the kool-aid. Anyone with half the average IQ can get in. If you're holding a good university degree, please don't waste your time and seek better professions elsewhere.
In this role, there are only two things you can do day in and day out. Cold call people, and convince them to purchase insurance products. If you're not an insurance specialist, you get the added privilege of selling housing loans and unit trusts. Don't kid yourself with the idea that you're helping people - 99% of WPMs are doing it for the commission, so do ahead and employ dirty tricks to get that money. (Don't quote me on this.)
Management is a hit or miss depending on where you are deployed to. Managers are former top sales WPMs. That's the only criteria aside from having your boss favour you. You're blessed if you have any form of capable mentorship to help you excel at your role. Expect long work hours cold-calling people. Does not stimulate me.
That said, depending on your colleagues around you, work environment is fantastic. Expect some sexism, homophobia and racial ignorance, but that's pretty typical.

Backend operations is completely incompetent. Try to get in touch with any operation support team and face a dead end. Lack of seamless communication within their own internal structure makes processes more complicated than they should be.

If you are keen on joining, think hard and long about the career path you wish to attain. Ensure that you have a transferable skillset should you opt out of banking/insurance sales, or stay on and hope you make it to management. Even after all that I have said, the possible career progression is still decent.

pros: Established local bank with growing reputation in Asia region. Strong Asian culture and value. Provide employees with courses to enrich themselves further. Good benefits such as high number of leaves and medical coverage.
cons: While certain jobs allow work-life balance, some jobs require OT till very late almost daily. Pay wise is acceptable as a local bank, but considerably low as compared with prestigious foreign banks.

pros: Pretty good benefits. Nice pantry, and the physical environment is pretty modern and technologically updated. Building looks nice. Security is quite top-notch. Bank takes care to protect customers' details.
cons: Unable to utilise benefits/leave (subject to approval), demanding supervisors, colleagues are those who will stab you behind your back. Keeps changing policies. HR spews propaganda but in reality, working environment is not that great.

review_title: Need to be politically savvy, not much recognition for talent. Politics takes priority over talent
pros:
Good Salary and benefits. 
Good brand to work for.
cons:
Lacks in technology Strategy. Though employee benefits are good, employee welfare is not a priority. Very superficial.

Training not in line with role performed.

review_title: Customer Service Officer at Call Center Department, 6 months plus. 0/10 Do not recommend.
pros:
Benefits are good, 24 days AL 2 day family care leave, 30 days medical leave. 
Colleagues are very nice people, they will go extra to help out.
cons:
1. Applying for leave at the call center department is very difficult and there is an unwritten rule that it is frowned upon. Managers will write people up for even taking sick leave which is unethical and ridiculous. 

2. Most team managers  only cares about meeting their own metrices, they don't care about the well being of their reports. If you are lucky you will get assigned to a good TM, otherwise your time there will be frustrating. 

3. If you do overtime it will be compensated as off in lieu. The catch is that it is so hard to get off, you might as well give them free OT. There are people trying to utilize their off in lieu for months but their requests are rejected with dumb reasons such as not able to take post shift off for pm shifts. 

4. Same problem for the rest of your leave. Birthday time off etc. since it is next to impossible to get them. 

5. Systems are unreliable and will fail at least 2 times every month but you are expected to get on without them. The back up system is useless and you cant access  the important files in the intranet you need for references. Any mistakes that you make even when systems are down is on you and will become part of your performance report. 

6. You will deal with difficult people every day. It is what the company is paying you for. Not recommended for the faint-hearted. Get ready to spend thousands on therapy.

review_title: Decent benefits and salary for an entry level position
pros: I came in through one of their graduate programs. The salary and benefits are competitive to that of the market.
cons: Though I'm in a grad program, there is little to none centralised training, which was different from the impression I got before I came in.

pros: The CEO has the right mindset and vision. If implemented correctly this bank can be regional powerhouse. However the senior and middle management is stuck in a 1980's mindset and resistant to change.
cons:
Too many entrenched middle managers who are afraid of new ideas
Hierarchical culture where things get done only by dropping a senior manager's name
High context culture

pros: Company is very big on going digital and improving innovation and is making the necessary steps to achieve it. Open to career mobility
cons: Culture is a bit too "local" - many old timers who've been with the bank since it's inception who can be resistant to change

pros: A work environment that will stretch you. Progressive tech adoption.
cons:
It’s a challenge working with business partners, who are not tech-savvy. Spent more time “educating” people and rewiring their mindset, rather than delivering and making a difference.

Middle and Senior Business Management are more interested in politics, than getting the job and results done. To them, “tech skills” relates more to ppt, spreadsheets and writing emails.

review_title: good pay but very bad work life
pros: good banking privileges, stable job, pay and bonus is competitive
cons: long hours, rigid.. not much work life balance. many employees come to work even though they are sick because the culture also does not encourage taking mc, even for pregnant colleagues that need to see gynae.

pros: people generally are nice. but seems standoffish due to the culture. Top management and CEO seems to have good view and values as to the direction of the bank.
cons:
most banks have many systems to toggle between for BAU. but it is my honest opinion that DBS takes the crown for the most number of system that serves at most 2 purpose each. i need 17 systems for bau.. all on a 15 inch laptop.
strong top management, weak mid management and unbalance ground staff. initiatives from top management makes sense and seems genuine in creating a good workplace and dependable bank. however, mid management either lack that foresight or are too busy in proving themselves that initiatives being cascaded down with very little effort in thoughts for the people on the ground. a team setup for a certain purpose is quickly overlooked about its objectives and overloaded due to poor management and planning. 
too many grey areas, archaic processes and systems. management too concern with pushing issues away and hover along the grey areas rather than embrace changes and acknowledge that its for the greater good to see every department as 1 bank rather than separate units.
mid management are too busy with proving themselves and giving results with no concern to staff. they take everything on and just throw it downwards with no deep understanding on how they want things to work. they only want to see the end results. when feedback on said issues, they only know how to ask for numbers and stats. extremely narrow minded.
lots of trainings and lofty ideas but none ive attended shows true reflection of management understanding what the real life is on the ground. when issues are brought up during trainings, trainers shrug and say speak to your manager. when you speak to your manager, they tell you not to get them in trouble. sure, CEO had invited people to contact him directly. but how many people are willing to disregard their livelihood and perhaps managers with good working relationships and contact the CEO directly.

pros:
Strong in Asia
Strong growth profile
Organization in transition
cons:
Organization in transition.
A regional middle-market organization trying to figure out how to be a player on a larger stage.
Too caught up in appearances. Not focused enough on what actually counts.

pros: It is a fast growing company which is looking to recruit talents. People here are generally friendly. As the headquarters is located in Singapore you do get to see and learn a lot of how decisions are made here.
cons: Management decisions are not agile and flexible enough to stay at the forefront of the competition. Depending on the departments, some do not value the contributions of the junior employees and practise limited work-life balance

review_title: Sell fluff and you'll fly sky high
pros: 24 days annual leave
cons:
- Some senior leaders are hypocritical: they project an ideal image on magazines but are complete opposite in reality 
- Ancient backend system 
- People who know how to present themselves well often get away from not doing work 
- Some BUs are known to splurge on expenditure while others struggle to even have budgets to get real proper work done.

pros: Lots to learn, good senior management, good training and working policies, lots of leave, transportation to and from work by shuttle bus
cons: Long hours in my department, Departmental politics, Too much work to handle in IT, distant location in Changi, might be mundane work

review_title: DBS Bank doesn't grow internal staff. They prefer to recruit externally.
pros: They observe work life balance, give good employees benefits.
cons: Promotion are not fair and square. There is also no yearly salary increment. The staff work like hell, but in the end management manipulate ratings of the staff''s appraisals.

review_title: Challenging in both good and bad ways
pros: You will be stretched to do new things. It's very performance and outcome driven so there is pressure, but increasingly encouraging a fail better learning environment and culture.
cons: Traditional hierarchy style of management. Politics abound and you may not be able to get things done as directly as they should be. Some managers are still abusive in the way they talk.

pros: Many benefits (e.g. medical, holiday claims, etc...), excellent colleagues and superiors.  Lots of events (corporate or personal) to mingle with your colleagues and superiors.
cons: Can get a little stressful when you do not hit your target.  Definitely not a 9 to 5 job.  More like 8 to 8.

pros: The pay is good, the leave is good, the medical benefits are excellent. Monetary wise, a perfect company. Good reputation. Great for stepping stone.
cons:
Contact Centre has high attrition rate than normal in 2013 due to a change in management.
Appraisal was hardly fair. Doubt any attempt to try to be fair in the department. Performance framework is well developed but it is often abused.

pros: Family-like working environment despite the difference in posts, the hierarchy rarely matters. The staffs have no qualms helping on another despite their workload as well.
cons: In the working environment, the job can be rather monotonous at times and there isn't much learning that could be done.

pros: Good staff benefits and frequent engagement of staff in events. Work a lot with foreigners in a fast paced environment.
cons: Very regimental where numbers are very important and in most cases illogical. People do not question the management despite the illogical decisions sometimes. Feels like I am working with robots and machine

review_title: IT Professional Suicide.. Everything is FAKE
pros:
- Good Salary
- Stable
- Good WorkMates
- If you are used to do nothing, this is your place
- If you love copy paste from a web, to a excel, to an email.. this is your place.
cons:
Everything about DBS Technology, is false. Pure propaganda, nothing is real.
The job descriptions are absolutely misleading to hunt talent and waste it, you may be applying for a specific position but you will be doing something totally different and irrelevant.
DBS is stuck in the 90's IBM ways and achieve technology goals is barely impossible, perform basic tasks can take you months of bureaucracy.
Terrible monitoring and alerting fully surrounded of old fashion technologies 99.9% just Java.. not much room for improvement (No Docker, No Python, No Go, No real Cloud, No IaaC, No Labs) as LOBs are totally decoupled from TS who controls everything and do nothing.

The offices are the worst environment i've worked so far in my 15+ years of career, to a point that I had daily skin rashes.. you can walk around and see desks or rugs not cleaned in one year... a real shame for a bank that waste so much money in unnecessary proprietary software but cut costs in keeping clean the work environments... DBS is under a transformation, which Is mainly about rename teams to trend labels, the tasks stills old-fashion and obsolete. They talk too much about Agile and DataDriven.. but the only thing of Agile that this organization do is avoid documentation at all.

 I could not fit in this organization and decided to left because the position was like everything else in this place, fake.

review_title: Long time employees are DBS worst enemy
pros: Stable well paid job, subordinates never challenges whats being said and done
cons:
Politics is everything, performance or technical knowledge has no value at all in managements eyes. 
Long timers hide information from newbies or even make fun of them just to slow down their work. 
Middle managers are not experienced enough to know what is important so they are easily fooled by people with the loudest voice.
 Talanted people usually leave the company rather quick.

pros:
- Great environment
- Good career advancement, given the right team and opportunity
- Good and competitive salary, and great benefits!
- Technology wise, the most advanced amongst the local banks
- Great CEO and leadership, with a strong and clear vision
- Best digital bank in the world!
- Best bank in the world!
cons: Can't complain much. I really enjoy working there.

pros: Good working environment, people are helpful and willing to provide guidance. Depending on your department, bosses are supportive of job rotation after 2 years with the bank. A good place to gain exposure in the bank. Employees are highly sought after in the market.
cons: Long working hours and stressful. No work-life balance. Management tends to give priority in career advancement for the management associates. Annual appraisal is not transparent,

pros: Affable colleagues and culture. Good employee benefits
cons: No consistency throughout the bank department.

review_title: FXMM, NDF, SWAP, precious metal, Fixed Income
pros: Welfare, 5@5, SOS, 26 days annual leave, Big dnd, cheap n delicious food in canteen, shuttle bus, family day, many in house courses to attend.
cons: Super Long working hours, lousy management style, lousy system, many extra / unnecessary tasks created to suppose help staff but at the end, adding more things to staff to perform.

review_title: Stable job with steady low increment
pros:
Stable job
Relative friendly environment
Company's culture and policy constantly being improved
Middle banding can expect around 5% increment
Good for people who are well paid before they join the bank because they get both high salary and stability!
cons:
Relatively lower paid compared to foreign banks.
Lack of international exposure
Relatively slow career progression for people who first join the financial industry

pros: Good culture, increasingly dynamic and expanding. Given ample opportunities and team is supportive. So far there is also minimal concern about job security.
cons: Can be quite messy at times and can be quite political as well depending on the situation. Bank need to scale up if it wants to be a force to be reckoned with

review_title: Be ready to be treated like dirt
pros: If you want just want salary and dont want to achieve anything meaningful, this is the place
cons:
Many: 
- The bosses are mediocre people who just want to grab all the success all the time
- Unless you are part of the team that is in favor, your success is limited
- It is not a place for meritocracy... age and time spent is awarded more
- Tremendous amount of discrimination - Indians / Indonesians though work hard, they are not treated well

pros: Great employee benefits, lots of leaves entitlement and opportunities for internal mobility
cons: People who are looking for work life balance and family centric place, this wouldn't be an ideal place to be.

review_title: Strong culture and trying to evolve constantly
pros:
Dynamic and trying to follow foreign banks culture. 
Strong digitalization directives from CEO and every bosses will try to fulfill
cons:
Because there's no hire and fire, there are bound to have some dead wood in the organization 
There's always a challenge to change mentality of some to change mindset

job_title: Graduate Associate Retail Banking (Sales) in Singapore
pros:
Challenging platform for one to learn the ropes of the trade.
DBS is legitimate and has a good branding.
cons:
Too much work.
KPIs are quite hard.
A big push on insurance sales instead of things like unit trusts. 
Getting your leave approved is a luxury.
Fail to explain the employment package fully before individuals sign the contract.
Under-promise.

pros: Time office 9-6, great colleague and boss of mine, many perks. Since my manager is great person. I could learn many things and explore things.
cons: So many bureaucracy  in making decisions, hard to make a new change if related to the business matter. Sometimes request a thing that the timing and requirement are not make sense.

pros: - Near respectable shopping centres if you like shopping
cons:
- Lots of "veterans" as colleagues
- not convenient location
- if miss shuttle bus service, need to walk at least 15 mins from MRT but if you like walking, good for you

pros: Good brand names. Many perks
cons: Many transition going on where policies owners are changed. Sometimes new policy owners or their staff does not have much ideas about the new portfolio they are having which makes it difficult to get things done. Too many changes and very disruptive.

pros: Stable local bank that needs no introduction. I was lucky to be promoted quite fast during my term with the bank. Had good bosses I guess.
cons: Extremely high volume because of the number of clients in DBS hence resulting in long hours. HR has a habit of putting a quota on the number of people to be promoted so it's not entirely based on your merits.

review_title: Ever growing in strength and leading the pack.
pros: Solid culture and management that is enabling the whole organisation and participants to be led in clear manner. We have confidence and clarity from top management of where the bank is heading.
cons: Too many systems, downtimes, productivity concerns such that customer experienced are still found wanting by many users and also by staff. Understaffed in some branches.

review_title: Nice Place with Learning Opportunities and Smart People
pros: If you are lucky, you can be working with a really smart team, and people with very good work ethics whom you definitely look up to and learn from them.  Ample opportunities to learn at work as well as through external training.
cons: Hours can be long sometimes. Internal process can be inefficient at times which cause a lot of menial tasks and time being wasted

review_title: It pays to be a cog
pros: I liked the role, primarily because it paid well. Other compensation benefits were also adequate and matched my expectations (even slightly exceeding it).
cons: It was too structured, perhaps to a fault. The hierarchy was intensive leaving no flexibility in terms of innovating. This really changed the experience from a positive one to a neutral one.

pros: Passionate, Relationship Led, Integrity Focused, Dedicated to Teamwork, Excelling with Confidence - Good management level with clear strategic goals makes this bank one of the best in region.
cons: Especially for the technology departments, I wouldn't advice as there is a huge proportion of contracted employees through vendors. To become perm, they are working unnecessary more hours (giving away the work-life balance) and this creates an unfair competition for perm employees.

review_title: Work Experience at Treasury Market Operations
pros: Friendly and cheerful environment. Staff benefits are above average in terms of claims, leaves, sick benefits and others.
cons: Not a department for people looking into finance jobs. Long working hours and unpaid overtime hours.

pros: Very chill, friendly and everyone is willing to teach you. I was able to learn a lot since my supervisor assigned me to different desks sometimes when I done with work early. Training is definitely very structured and outstanding in DBS and working environment is very good.
cons: Sometimes the work can get boring - but really depends on which department you are in and what type of work you are interested.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bukit Merah Estate,
pros: good benefits,  good welfare, people are generally nice on the surface
cons: quite political, hierarchical, must suck it up to bosses to make it, progression depends on tenure in bank rather than whether your performance is good or not, at least for my department. work-life balance is quite tough, as the work load keeps piling up very quickly

review_title: Having worked in multiple SME and also government jobs prior to DBS, this is the best the best you can get
pros: Employee Benefits especially annual leave. Supportive colleagues from within the same team/department.
cons: Long hours especially for those working in BO. Projects that require cross department/unit efforts may face challenges especially when those departments/units are just supporting the project rather than leading them. Processes can be very confusing for new joiner

review_title: Progressive but too strict on compliance
pros: Good for those who want progression and is OK with lesser commissions. You can do lateral movement around the bank after 2 years. One of the few banks that is still aggressively expanding unlike the western banks.
cons: From sales perspective, a lot lower commissions and incentives compared to the 'blue local bank'. Compliance controls are almost too stringent to a fault.

review_title: Not a very inspiring place to be
pros: Being the premier flag ship of Singapore has its benefits.
cons: You will do well if you can navigate the political mine field. Growth of an employee depends on political affiliations and not on his/ her competency

pros:
1. Good place to build career
2. Good compensation package
3. Continuous effort by management to evolve the culture to ensure a more comprehensive company
cons:
1. Management communication need to improve
2. Very political 
3. Process and procedure maturity need to further improve
4. No work life balance

review_title: I had a switch of role however i feel that people here are under appreciated.
pros: Leave allowance, distance from home, benefits provided
cons: Underpaid, overpromised by immediate leader, not appreciated if you "cannot be seen"

review_title: Not a bad place if you want a stable job
pros: Good bonus, good trainings available, generally friendly culture
cons: Strategy not aligned among different departments, not very innovative, every departments need to be working together to achieve common goal - therefore KPI across departments have to be aligned, middle management needs to be trained more how to lead their teams.

review_title: I worked in the consumer investment and insurance products group in the commercial bank as a summer analyst.
pros:
Great mentorship there from everyone in the team
Alot of opportunities to interact with senior management
Wide variety of work to do, although not very challenging.
cons:
Easy and mundane work due to it being commercial banking.
They hire 95% from the local universities which makes it a very stagnant culture.
Lack of opportunities to get fulltime employment.

pros: 24 days AL + 2 days family leave
cons:
Don't even have a designated seat at work.
You can forget about having any holidays once join as you will be ask to come back with oil reimbursement which you can never get to claim back due to their service level being consistently bad.

pros: the brand name of the company
cons:
my boss was a slave driver who did not promote work life balance. 
and my supervisor did not care if i could cope with my work load. 
there was very little engagement.

review_title: DBS is considered one of the safest banks globally and has a strong presence in Asia.
pros: Good work life balance with competitive benefits. Strong management who consider inputs from all employees. Has been consistently improving in terms of profitability.
cons: Base salaries are not as competitive as other foreign banks hence it is not able to attract as many talents. However, overall package is still competitive.

review_title: A performance driven work environment with strong emphasis on digifying processes, with pretty good staff benefits
pros: Clear KPIs set out, has strong customer base, and staff empowerment. Remuneration is competitive as compared to industry and staff benefits are good
cons: Fully sales based and slightly longer hours in business unit. No time to partake in part time further studies. Efforts to capture/retain market share is very strong.

job_title: Vice President in Bedok New Town,
pros: Lots of Free Time, Lots of Leave, People run businesses on the side with no employer over-sight
cons: Lazy Colleagues who are entitled and think they have employment for life so dont want to work.

pros: Best bank in the world, what more is there to say?
cons: At times, you wish you could put in a little more hours, spend a little more time with your financial model, and build stronger bonds with your colleagues in the team.. the bank has an emphasis on work life balance and spending more time with family is actively encouraged.

pros:
-Good employee benefits
-Stable iron rice bowl job
-well know for its brand now
cons:
-too competitive
-don't have much work life balance
-Whichever rank you in,  doesn't justify the amount of work you received
-Senior management may know high level things, but they tends to oversight the lower level things and just continue on their decision.

pros: Benefits are quite good. Number of leaves given in a year is a lot compared to other companies.
cons: Overworked and underpaid. KPI has been increased by a lot while pay has not been increased by much. Management don’t really see the work environment at branches as a “show” is put up when they do visit.

pros: It is a good place to work with cooperative co-workers. Bosses are very driven and focus. Benefits are better than most companies.
cons: It's lacking in well written process and tools. A lot of unnecessary red tapes which impairs ones output. Work load is on the high side.

pros: Management is actively engaged in pushing the frontiers of banking, and studying best practices globally to import some of the learning points back home
cons: Period of transition in terms of cultural change. Some managers might not be able to adapt well.

pros: Bonus, leave, remuneration, colleagues, I flex
cons: Opportunity is zero. They pay OT in terms of vouchers and hours. But we never had the chance to choose which hour we want to pick. They will give randomly on the same day.

pros:
• You can see the project you're working on go live within 6-9 months
• Good people to work with.
cons:
• Technology is still not update to date. Lots of time, product/features got cut down because Technology can't deliver due to their infrastructure and knowledge base.
• No time to think and proper develop products.

review_title: Starting Your day with the Best Bank in the World !
pros: Engaging Atmosphere, Dynamic Work, Looking forward to creating a Bank for the Future, Steep Learning Curve, Great Place which promotes Internal Mobility, Fast, Agile and Dynamic Workplace
cons: Processes are still getting set, Awareness & Branding for the Bank still lacking

pros:
Management is very organised
Good Employee Benefits
Good Salary
Efforts are appreciated
cons: Depends on your managers. If u have a good manager, you will have a work-life balance. Otherwise, you will work and work and work.

pros:
- Flexibility
- Amazing team 
- Very open culture
- Protective
cons: How your life will turn out to be in the bank will depend on your team manager.

pros: Attractive pay scheme and lots of employee benefits to retain staff
cons: Top down structure where how much you're expected to work relates directly to which manager you're tagged to. If you're lucky you get to work smart, else pray and prepare to put in the hours for a job that can be finished in half the time.

pros: good work life balance, good benefits, competitive remuneration, happy to work there, would recommend someone to work there
cons: long working hours, company culture not the best, company politics, not the best workplace environment to be in, management do not provide support

review_title: DBS - a great place to work!!!
pros:
- Forward-looking organisation that makes us all proud to be part of the bank
- Great managers that empowers us to try new things
- Have the flexibility to work from home
- Great benefits with various types of leave and even a shares scheme
- Continuously develop new tech infrastructure to help productivity at work
cons: Too many projects, too little time!

pros:
Benefits are great. 
There is work life balance
CEO has a vision and clear direction  for the company
Supports employee having young children
cons:
Bosses are still rigid in their mindset and not open to the idea of working elsewhere or from home
Departments are still working very silo and little collaboration though the company is encouraging and moving towards that.

review_title: Blend of East and West Cultures
pros: Loads of clientele. Micromanagement kept to a moderate level. Entire bank has a singular purpose and clarity in its goals and objectives.
cons: Compensation is on the lower end in the industry. Technology is outdated but slowly improving.

pros:
Rotation around the bank (but to be changed from 2019 onwards)
Face time with senior management
cons:
Uncertainty of rotations.
HR not transparent and gets very defensive when questioned.
Equalizing masters and bachelors pay.
Total compensation for masters less than bachelors, both in absolute amount and in % terms.
Undervalued the masters education despite originally pushing for a masters focused hiring.

review_title: Great working environment and culture, but progression is slow
pros:
• friendly and helpful colleagues
• good working environment 
• flexible work hours
• shuttle buses provided
• good employee welfare and benefits
cons:
• work progression is very slow
• have to work at least 3-4 years before promotion
• high volume of work
• hires the wrong people for the job

pros: If you get a good BBM your days at work is heavenly, even tho it’s a sales role.
cons: If you get a bad BBM, then best is if you resign and find something better

pros: good training environment for new staff which is conducted at changi business park
cons: asian bank will always be asian bank. like to eat staff and squeeze you dry. underpay and force you to leave or resign if they dont like you. bully new staff

review_title: In the midst of having my internship there. Would say I like the culture of the good. My department has lots of activities for bonding. My colleagues are nice too.
pros: Can knock off early on Friday, 5pm. But this varies among departments and among of workload you have.
cons: Haven't experience anything bad. So far so good.

pros: Job stability; offers good staff benefits; and high staff engagement.
cons: Some system enhancements put up by Operations to improve productivity are slow to implement or rejected due to lack of budget.

pros: Good benefits, good employee share ownership scheme, centralised location of headquarters
cons: Poor progression for rank and file staff not in talent or management associate program, poor annual increment of 2%, low engagement of business HR for rank and file employees. Very poor work life balance, high demands and poor rewards.
